intro: Andromeda glaucophylla var. latifolia, commonly known as the broad-leaved leatherleaf, is a flowering plant native to the southeastern United States. It is a member of the Ericaceae family, which includes heathers and blueberries, and is characterized by its evergreen foliage and showy, bell-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, acidic soils and is often found in shaded, forested areas. Its leaves are thick and leathery, and the flowers are usually pink or white, blooming in the spring. This variety is distinguished by its broader leaves compared to the typical form of Andromeda glaucophylla.
